Award.AwardTitle: PIRE: Low Energy Options for Making Water from Wastewater
Award.AbstractNarration: Climate change and global population growth demand creative, low-energy, multi-disciplinary, and multi-benefit approaches to sustaining water resources. This PIRE will catalyze, through research and education, the development and deployment of low-energy options for improving water productivity while protecting human and ecosystem health. The project links five different universities in two water-stressed regions of the world (southwest U.S. and southeast Australia) with unique and complementary expertise in the development and deployment of rainwater tanks, biofilters, and waste stabilization ponds for potable substitution and watershed protection. Research will: (1) improve the removal of pathogens and micropollutants in storm water runoff by harnessing solar energy and incorporating into biofilter design the plant and animal communities native to local seasonal wetlands; (2) investigate the risks and benefits of distributed adoption of these technologies on public health, energy consumption, and greenhouse gas emissions; (3) identify social, economic, and policy barriers to their adoption, quantify their unpriced benefits and propose economic instruments, regulations, and public education measures to foster their adoption; and (4) quantify the impact of distributed adoption of these technologies on urban stream hydrology, water quality, and ecology. Broader impacts include green technology for treating runoff and gray water at the household scale; dissemination of research results to managers and engineers; a diverse workforce in sustainability science; an electronic textbook (E-book) on Water Sustainability; K-12 teaching modules with research-integrated summer activities, including BioFilter Frenzy Week; and education programs targeting Native American high school students and science teachers throughout the U.S.. The project is funded by NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE) through its PIRE program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Low Energy Options for Making Water from Wastewater (OISE-1243543, 10/12-09/17, $4,858,314).

Intellectual merit. Climate change and global population growth demand creative, low-energy, multi-disciplinary, and multi-benefit approaches to sustaining adequate water resources. Through integrative research across five different universities in the southwest U.S. and southeast Australia, this PIRE project catalyzed the development and deployment of low-energy options for improving water productivity while protecting human and ecosystem health.  The project had four overarching goals, as follows.

Goal 1 (Knowledge/Research/Discovery): working with research and industrial partners our research team carried out multidisciplinary research on urban water sustainability, including: (1) field studies aimed at characterizing chemical and microbiological contaminants in stormwater runoff from urban areas in Southern California and Australia; (2) process based studies of low energy approaches for removing chemical and microbiological contaminants in stormwater runoff using terrestrial technologies (such as stormwater biofilters, also known as rain gardens, and stormwater wetlands) and natural in situ treatment (NIST) technologies in urban runoff impacted streams, such as hyporheic exchange treatment systems; (3) evaluation of the ecosystem, public safety, and human health risks associated with using terrestrial and NIST technologies for removing pollutants from stormwater runoff, including greenhouse gas emissions, heavy metal accumulation, flood risk, and quantitative microbial risk assessment (QMRA) associated with non-potable uses of partially treated stormwater runoff; (4) institutional barriers to the adoption of fit-for-purpose uses of stormwater runoff, and low energy natural treatment technologies; and (5) systems level studies of storm water governance, management, and policy.

Since the project was funded (in late 2012) our PIRE team has published 46 papers and one book, with several more research articles in various stages of submission and revision. These research products were published in some of the best journals in our respective fields (including a prestigious Report in the journal Science), and include a mix of focused studies coauthored by a subset of the PIRE team (usually with PIRE funded undergraduate students, graduate students, and/or postdoctoral researchers) and discipline spanning “hive mind” papers typically coauthored by most of the PIRE team. 

Goal 2 (Education and Workforce Development): education and workforce development activities occurred at all four levels, including: (1) a graduate student led K12 outreach program called H2Outreach, that provided hands on activities for hundreds of elementary school children in Orange County about urban water sustainability; (2) an immersive multidisciplinary summer field experience in Australia for undergraduate students hailing from the three participating UC campuses (UCI, UCLA, and UCSD); (3) graduate level research opportunities with U.S. and Australian faculty; and (4) field research in the U.S. and Australia for three full-time postdoctoral researchers.

H2Outreach participated in four events with 23 volunteers reaching 16 K12 schools and approximately 704 K12 students. Our Undergraduate PIRE Program (or "UPP Down Under") brought a total of 48 undergraduates to Australia over the four years of the project, and many of these former students are now in prestigious graduate programs or working in the environmental field. Six graduate students finished their PhDs over the four years of the project, and three more are in progress. After graduating, all of these PhD students found gainful employment in government, industry, or academic positions. The three PIRE-funded post-docs are now faculty members at R1 universities.

Goal 3 (Partnerships): partnerships were fostered with a broad range of industrial partners from both the U.S. and Australia, including personnel from engineering consulting firms, government managers responsible for stormwater drainage and wastewater treatement, and drinking water purveyors. These relationships were nutured through annual workshops in the U.S ,and Australia, virtual conferences, and one-on-one meetings between faculty and interested partners. Altogether, faculty associated with the PIRE fostered 37 new partnerships, including 11 with universities, 18 with non-profit organizations, and 8 with government agencies. 

Goal 4 (Institutional Capacity): efforts to enhance the institutional capacity of the cooperating UC campuses primarily focused on the development of water- focused campus institutes (such as Water UCI, led by co-PI Feldman) and the successful submission of center proposals, including a multi-million dollar award from teh UC Office of the President led by PI Grant.

Broader Impacts. Our research garnered significant interest from the general public and engineering practice communities. For example, our research has been written about and featured in newspapers (Washington Post, New York Times), magazines (Scientific American, Motherboard), radio (National Public Radio), and trade journals (IEEE’s Global 360 magazine and a Web Exclusive article in ASCE’s Civil Engineering Magazine). The principles we articulated for managing urban runoff were adopted in Orange County’s 2016 assessment of its stormwater infrastructure (as part of the ASCE Infrastructure Report Card effort), and may very well end up being adopted nationally. The publishing house Edward Elgar Inc. (UK) published (in 2017) our PIRE inspired book on urban water sustainability authored by co-PI Feldman and colleagues (The Water Sustainable City: Science, Policy, and Practice).
